meanings.def: a container made of wood, thick card, metal, etc. with a flat stiff base and sides and often a lid (= cover), used especially for holding solid things
examples: in a box Everything we owned was neatly packed in cardboard boxes.
She kept all the letters in a box.
inside a box Do you know what is inside the box?
She opened her money box to see if she had saved enough for a tennis racket.
a toolbox
a matchbox
She filled the box with old clothes.
The dog sleeps in a box lined with an old blanket.
The exhibition is free, but there is a collection box for donations.
They were sitting around the fire on upturned boxes.
This box holds ten candles and costs $21.40.
We packed all the books into boxes.
a box marked ‘fragile’

meanings.def: a box and its contents; the things a box contains
examples: a box of chocolates/cereal/tissues
He produced a box of matches from his pocket.
People buy low-fat cookies and then eat the whole box.

meanings.def: a square or rectangle on a page or computer screen for people to put information in or containing extra or different information
examples: Put a cross in the appropriate box.
(British English) to tick a box
(North American English) to check a box
Type your query in the search box.
There are over 300 special note boxes in the dictionary.
Put a cross in the box if you agree with the comments.
Tick the appropriate box below.
The basic search screen includes two text boxes for words to be searched.
A box pops up on the monitor providing a customer profile.
Please offer your own ideas in the comment box at the end of this blog.

meanings.def: a small area in a theatre, court or sports stadium, separated off from where other people sit
examples: The painting depicts two elegantly dressed women in a box at the opera.
The judge addressed the 12 people seated in the jury box.
They drank champagne as they watched the game from the executive box.

meanings.def: a small shelter used for a particular purpose
examples: a sentry/signal box
(British English, old-fashioned) a telephone box
I called him from the phone box on the corner.
There was a babble of languages in the commentary box when the race began.

meanings.def: the television
examples: on the box What's on the box tonight?

meanings.def: a place where two roads cross or join, marked with a pattern of yellow lines to show that vehicles must not stop in that area
examples: Only traffic turning right may enter the box.

meanings.def: an area on a sports field that is marked by lines and used for a particular purpose
examples: (British English) He was fouled in the box (= the penalty box).

meanings.def: a number used as an address, especially one given in newspaper advertisements to which replies can be sent
a piece of plastic that a man wears over his sex organs to protect them while he is playing a sport, especially cricket
a small evergreen tree or bush with thick dark leaves, used especially for garden hedges
the hard wood of the box tree
a set of methods or equipment that somebody can use
examples: Hotel managers are using a whole new bag of tricks to attract their guests.

meanings.def: to hit somebody with your hand on the side of their head as a punishment
to think about something, or how to do something, in a way that is new, different or shows imagination
to do exactly the right things to please somebody
examples: This is a movie that ticks all the boxes.
The house we would like to buy ticks all our boxes.

idioms.def: a set of methods or equipment that somebody can use
examples: Hotel managers are using a whole new bag of tricks to attract their guests.

idioms.idiom: give somebody a box on the ears
idioms.def: to hit somebody with your hand on the side of their head as a punishment

meanings.def: to fight somebody in the sport of boxing
examples: He boxed for Ireland in the Olympics.
The newcomer boxed the champion for the full twelve rounds.

meanings.def: to put something in a box
examples: She boxed the decorations up and put them in the attic.

meanings.def: to act in a clever way to get what you want, sometimes tricking somebody
examples: Suzie realized that she had to box clever. She had to let Adam think she trusted him.
